Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding the reactivity of hydrogen atoms in solid parahydrogen
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms A (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry Professor Robert J. Hinde of the Department of Chemistry of the University of Tennessee Knoxville and Professor David T. Anderson of the Chemistry Department of the University of Wyoming and their postdoctoral, graduate and undergraduate student researchers are working on a collaborative theoretical and experimental effort to understand the low-temperature reactivity of hydrogen atoms with other molecules in the ultra-cold environment of solid hydrogen. They are investigating the unique chemistry in these unusual systems, where the ordinary rules of chemistry do not apply. This research could shed light on the chemistry that takes place in non-terrestrial systems. Young scientists working on this project will receive excellent training in experimental physical chemistry and computational chemistry research.

Prof. Hinde and Anderson are investigating the interesting reactivity of H atoms in para hydrogen matrices. These are ultra-cold environments where the effects of quantum mechanical behavior can dominate the reactivity. Among the topics being investigated are: (1) the study of the temperature dependence of H-atom reactions, where some reactions show Arrhenius behavior while others show abrupt increases at low temperatures; (2) determine H-atom solvation energies, where there is a subtle interplay between kinetic and potential energy contributions and fully-quantum many body methods need to be employed; and (3) the further development of infrared spectroscopic tools for investigating these systems. The chemical systems being studied include H + H2, H + N2O, H + NO, H + HCN, and H + C2H2. Students working in the groups of Hinde and Anderson will receive state-of-the-art training in advanced computational chemistry and low-temperature chemical physics, respectively. Both groups of students will benefit from close interaction with members of the other groups, broadening their training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This is a collaborative research project between Professor Robert J. Hinde (theory) at the University of Tennessee and Professor David T. Anderson (experiment) at the University of Wyoming to study hydrogen atom reactions with various molecular species in solid parahydrogen at temperatures between 1.5 and 4.3 K. Typically chemistry occurs more slowly at low temperatures because reactants lack the necessary thermal energy to help break chemical bonds before new bonds can be formed.  At extremely low temperatures therefore, in principle, all chemistry should stop. However, nature is trickier than you think and at very low temperatures chemical reactions can still occur through a process called quantum mechanical tunneling. In this case the reactants do not surmount the barrier to a reaction, but rather tunnel through it. This is possible because atoms and molecules have very small masses and behave quantum mechanically at very low temperatures. When chemistry occurs exclusively through tunneling at extreme low temperatures, many of the chemical rules established for high temperature chemistry break down.

However, another reason we study low temperature tunneling reactions in cryogenic parahydrogen crystals is related to the special properties of solid parahydrogen. Solid parahydrogen forms crystalline solids below around 5 K that are characterized as quantum crystals. Basically each parahydrogen molecule in the crystal behaves more like a wave than a particle and thus the quantum crystal has properties of both a liquid and a solid, simultaneously. Then by creating hydrogen atoms (H atom) in solid parahydrogen using lasers, we create a very interesting chemical system whereby the H atom can move through the solid even at 0 K. Typically, atom diffusion in most solids is excruciatingly slow, but an H atom in solid parahydrogen is always moving due to quantum jumps from one lattice site to another. This means that we can study H atom tunneling reactions with other chemical species (e.g., N2O and NO) that we trap in the quantum crystal to learn more about this very cold chemistry. We studied a number of chemical reactions and found results that were qualitatively different from the analogous “high temperature” chemistry. The rates of these hydrogen atom tunneling reactions also give information on how the H atom diffuses through the quantum solid. One of the major findings of these studies is that the H atom appears to be moving by quantum diffusion.  That is, unlike regular Brownian diffusion that increases linearly with temperature, quantum diffusion is independent of temperature and therefore can show new types of dynamics. These studies have important ramifications for our understanding of chemical reactions at extreme low temperatures but also on the detailed quantum mechanical properties of H atoms under these low temperature conditions. Further, H atoms in solid parahydrogen are interesting quantum systems that may find uses as high energy rocket fuels, in quantum computing and quantum sensing. Both undergraduates and graduate students were involved in this research giving them excellent training in a variety of physical chemistry experimental and computational methods.
